{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3341304,"name":"Greg Middleton","username":"Greg6824","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ecccb3/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T14:24:10.246Z","cooked":"

Rookie team. We are using Logitech F310 joysticks. When we deploy KitBotCode the drivetrain works, so we know our electrical and CAN are good.

When we deploy with the Everybot Code, We don’t get any response when moving the joysticks on Controller 0 from the Bot.

When we look at the USB Order, we see Axes 1 (left Y) show motion when we move the stick, and Axes 4 (R X) as well.

I see the code looking at getRawAxis(axes:1), and axes:4 with the java code:

m_drivetrain.arcadeDrive(-m_driverController.getRawAxis(1), -m_driverController.getRawAxis(4), false);

Any advice on what we are not understanding between Kitbot java and the Everybot Java?

What port is the controller set as in the code and in drive station, these can differ. You can also reorder the controllers in drive station to change which controller is which port number. Check if it needs to be port 1 instead of 0.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Joysticks

A joystick can be used with the Driver Station program to control the robot. Almost any “controller” that can be recognized by Windows can be used as a joystick. Joysticks are accessed using the Ge...

Is it possible to share a fuller copy of your code?

I think we are good again. Although I’m confused as to what happened. We pulled one of the old Logitech flight joysticks off a shelf, and changed the code to use it for Drive Train on USB 3. That was working, went back and updated the code to use the F310 on port 0 for drivetrain; Deployed and we are working.

But I think this is all of the relevant code below

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Joystick;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.TimedRobot;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Timer;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.drive.DifferentialDrive;

 DifferentialDrive m_drivetrain;

  Joystick m_driverController = new Joystick(0);

  Joystick m_manipController = new Joystick(1);

m_drivetrain.arcadeDrive(-m_driverController.getRawAxis(1), -m_driverController.getRawAxis(4), false);

Yup drive is port 0 and operator is port 1. Another thing that can happen with the F310 is the switch on the bottom can get changed from X to D or vice-versa. If it’s not working that may be worth checking. It controls X-Input or Direct-Input

From the Logitech manual

XInput is the most current input standard for games on the Windows operating system. Most newer games that support gamepads use XInput. If your game supports XInput gamepads and your gamepad is in XInput mode all gamepad controls should operate normally. If your game supports XInput gamepads and your gamepad is in DirectInput mode, the gamepad will not function in the game unless it is switched to XInput mode or the gamepad is configured using the Logitech Profiler software. DirectInput is an older input standard for games on the Windows operating system. Most older games that support gamepads use DirectInput. If your game supports DirectInput gamepads and your gamepad is in XInput mode, most features on the gamepad will function except that the left and right trigger buttons act as a single button, not independently. For best support in DirectInput games, try putting the gamepad in DirectInput mode, marked “D” on the gamepad bottom (2).
